#Text=2. Self-Similar Graph Actions
#Text=We review the properties of self-similar graph actions defined by Exel and Pardo .
#Text=All the material in this section is taken from works .
#Text=Suppose that is a directed graph , where is the set of vertices , is the set of edges , d is the domain map , and r is the range map .
#Text=A directed graph E is called finite if and are finite sets .
#Text=For a natural number n , a path of length n in E is a finite sequence of the form where and for every i .
#Text=The domain and range of a are defined by and , respectively .
#Text=A vertex is considered as a path of length 0 , with .
#Text=If a and b are paths such that , then we denote the path obtained by juxtaposing a and b by .
#Text=We use to denote the length of a .
#Text=For every non-negative integer n , we denote the set of paths of length n in E by and define .
#Text=The set of right-infinite paths of the form is denoted by .
#Text=The product topology of a discrete set E is defined on .
#Text=The cylinder set for each is defined by
#Text=Then , the collection of all such cylinder sets forms a basis for the product topology on .
#Text=An automorphism of a directed graph E is a bijective map , such that for , , and on .
#Text=An action of a group G on a directed graph E is a group homomorphism from G to the group of all automorphisms of E .
#Text=To simplify the notation , we will adopt the shorthand notation
#Text=A self-similar graph action consists of a directed graph E and an action of a group G on E by automorphisms , with a one-cocycle , such that for all and ,
#Text=As Exel and Pardo showed in ( [ 6 ] Proposition 2.4 ) , the G action and one-cocycle extend to via the inductive formula for with , so that we have for every with .
#Text=In addition , the G action induces an action of G on given by
#Text=It is not difficult to obtain the following properties of restrictions .
#Text=For and with ,
#Text=A self-similar graph action is called pseudo-free if for any satisfying and , it holds that .
#Text=We say that the G action on is topologically free if is dense in for every .
#Text=A path in is said to have an entry if there is at least one such that has more than one element .
#Text=Assumption 1.
#Text=In this study , we assume the following ,
#Text=1 .
#Text=Every group is a finitely generated countable group ,
#Text=2 . every graph is a connected finite directed graph with the properties that every circuit has an entry and and are nonempty sets for every vertex ,
#Text=3 . every finite path has an entry ,
#Text=4 . our self-similar graph action is pseudo-free , and
#Text=5 . the G action on is topologically free .
#Text=Inverse Semigroups and Groupoids
#Text=Suppose that is a self-similar graph action .
#Text=An inverse semigroup of is defined as follows ( [ 6 ] §4 ) , with the binary operation defined by and the unitary adjoint operation defined by

#Text=The inverse semigroup has a canonical action on in terms of partial homeomorphisms : The domain of is and
#Text=We note that is the empty map .
#Text=Now , we briefly describe groupoids of germs of inverse semigroups and groups .
#Text=Let X be a locally compact Hausdorff space and S an inverse semigroup ( or a group ) acting on X .
#Text=Then , consider a set , and define an equivalence relation on by if and only if and s and t coincide on a neighborhood of x .
#Text=The equivalence class of every is called the germ of s at x , denoted by .
#Text=The set of every germ is a groupoid , called the groupoid of germs of S on X , whose operations are given by
#Text=The unit space is identified with X .
